stream_context.summary: Kaze builds and refines the craft-themed desert course for Return to Yoshi’s Island, experimenting with a home-made normal-mapping technique for N64 and blocking out new star objectives, props, and enemies.

development_findings.summary: Kaze added software-generated normal-map support to N64: the texture is computed on the CPU each frame and the GPU just renders the result, multiplying surface normals by the camera vector to fake styrofoam reflectivity.
development_findings.quote: The N64 does not have normal-map support. I added the support—the texture is computed on the CPU and the GPU just has to render it.

development_findings.summary: Normal map currently uses camera direction; switching to light direction would look more correct but would lose dynamism, so Kaze is experimenting with a hybrid that still responds to lighting.
development_findings.quote: If it only depended on the light direction it would be a static texture and it wouldn’t look good at all.

development_findings.summary: Level structure: six stars planned – (1) escort yellow crayon to a Luigi doodle to draw a star, (2) red-coin section inside pyramid, (3) paper-plane silver-star ride, (4) hidden cave entrance star, (5) 8-bit pipe star, (6) a final pure-platforming segment (originally ice, later pivoted to castle).

Interactive props blocked in: tilting bridge to Luigi area, rolling crayon used like a log, rubber-band or paper-spring launchers, popsicle-stick bridges, cardboard lock-rolling section, ruler trampoline.

Enemy plans: cardboard thwomp, womp, bob-omb, spindle; new craft-specific hazards like cardboard saw blades and roaming scissors; googly-eyed thwomps in desert; confetti blizzard for former snow idea.
Pivot: ice biome at course edge was dropped mid-stream and replaced with a castle zone because ice materials looked poor and costly; snow material ideas (cotton balls, sugar cubes) were shelved.
development_findings.quote: Maybe ice just doesn’t work. Maybe it should be volcano… Actually I’m changing this to a castle biome.

development_findings.summary: Flat ‘doodle’ NPCs (Yoshi, Luigi, Toad) are 2-D cut-outs (~35 tris) weighted to simple bones for cheap waving animations within Fast64’s 0/1 vertex-weight limit.
development_findings.quote: One idea I had is putting a bone in him and just have him wave back and forth… we only have vertex weights 1 or 0.

development_findings.summary: Popsicle-stick geometry is optimised: five vertices per stick; mushrooms were re-skinned with paper-plate umbrella textures after chat feedback.
Performance constraints: beveling styrofoam doubles texture count; a bevelled chunk hit 600 triangles; every additional surface orientation requires a separate pre-baked normal texture.
Emulator limitation: advanced F3DEX3 microcode and F3D extensions (like planned f3dex3 lighting tricks) are not yet widely supported, constraining effect choices.
development_findings.quote: If I do F3DEX3 stuff, emulators are holding us back—our stuff won’t run on emulator.

context_findings.summary: Kaze’s design principle: ‘You should spend more time thinking about what to create than you spend creating.’
context_findings.quote: You should spend more time thinking about what to create than you spend creating.

context_findings.summary: He dislikes 2-D drawing, preferring 3-D modelling; recounts refusing to doodle in school.
context_findings.quote: I still hate [drawing]; I’m just doing it so you leave me alone.

context_findings.summary: Frustration and mixed emotions over audience criticism of styrofoam texture; openly tests ideas live and pivots when feedback is negative.
Casual financial note: received a $50 donation (‘that’s like 10 burgers’) indicating modest personal funding via stream tips.
Humorous personal banter about work habits, One Piece, and avoiding cancellation; stream showcases relaxed, unfiltered personality.

biobak.summary: Reworking several of Kaze’s older levels and provided feedback/art; delivered Yoshi/Luigi doodle artwork that Kaze imported.
biobak.quote: Biobak is helping me rework some of my levels.

badub.summary: Composing most of the game’s soundtrack; ‘desert music’ for this course is expected from him.
badub.quote: Badub is making most of the music.

zeina.summary: Brief appearance in chat; Kaze mentions they play-test Mario Kart together and jokes about personal life on stream.

key_stories.title: Hacking Normal Maps onto the N64
key_stories.summary: Kaze wants styrofoam cliffs to glint realistically. The N64 has no normal-mapping, so he writes CPU code to generate a per-frame texture simulating it, multiplying normals by the camera vector. Viewers debate correctness, leading him to refine the math and accept limitations like sharp edges.
key_stories.challenge: Create dynamic, reflective styrofoam lighting on hardware that officially lacks normal maps.
key_stories.process: Computed normals on CPU each frame; experimented with camera vs light vectors; tested bevel counts and texture density; live feedback guided tweaks.
key_stories.outcome: Effect works but is performance-heavy and visually imperfect; Kaze will iterate further before locking style.
key_stories.key_quote: The N64 does not have normal-map support. I added the support—the texture is computed on the CPU and the GPU just has to render it.

key_stories.title: Crayon Escort Star
key_stories.summary: For Star 1, a cardboard Luigi doodle asks Mario to fetch a yellow crayon across a sandy craft zone. The player crosses a tilting bridge, battles enemies, carries the crayon back, and draws a star.
key_stories.challenge: Design a star objective that showcases craft props and item-carry mechanics.
key_stories.process: Blocked out bridge, enemy area, crayon pick-up, and Luigi NPC; moved red-coin star elsewhere to keep flow clean.
key_stories.outcome: Puzzle path is mapped; needs enemy placement and scripting.
key_stories.key_quote: The Luigi doodle is gonna be like ‘I need a yellow crayon to finish my star’ and then you have to go over here… and bring him the doodle and then you draw the star.

key_stories.title: Mushroom Redesign via Paper Plates
key_stories.summary: Chat hated the low-res mushroom caps. Kaze searches live for better craft textures, settles on red paper plates with white decals, models them within minutes, and the audience applauds the ‘sexy’ new mushrooms.
key_stories.challenge: Original mushroom caps looked blurry and unconvincing.
key_stories.process: Scoured texture sites, extracted a suitable plate texture, multi-textured it, adjusted decal dots.
key_stories.outcome: Improved aesthetic and positive community response; demonstrates agile iteration.
key_stories.key_quote: Dude, these mushrooms are sexy… I like this a lot.

open_questions.context: CPU-generated textures per orientation are heavy; beveling doubles texture count.
questions: How much CPU time and texture memory does the normal-map system consume per frame?
Will it run on real hardware without framerate drops?

open_questions.context: Kaze abruptly swapped planned ice zone for a castle theme but gave minimal explanation.

open_questions.context: Many craft enemies are listed (saw blades, scissors, cardboard thwomp/womp) but none are built yet.

open_questions.context: Badub is composing ‘most of the music’, but no timeline or workflow was detailed.
